formatted_items.arguments:
{"to":["mark@baxterassociates.com"],"subject":"Re: Inquiry on Procedural Strategy","body":"Hi Mark,

Thank you for getting in touch. I’m happy to share a few high-level points that tend to guide our approach when preparing and filing motions in state court:

1. Calendar and Local Rules
• Start by working backward from the hearing date or desired ruling date, and double-check any court-specific or holiday-related adjustments to the ordinary response periods.
• Keep an eye on word-count and formatting limits contained in local rules—those small details are among the most common grounds for rejection.

2. Meet-and-Confer
• Most divisions now expect a documented good-faith conferral. I usually send a brief email and include a certification in the motion itself. Omitting this step can lead to an outright denial without prejudice.

3. Supporting Materials
• Attach only what the judge truly needs: the motion, memorandum of law, and a concise proposed order. Number all pages consecutively so the court’s electronic viewer lines up with your citations.
• When exhibits are essential, highlight the exact portions you’ll cite during argument to save the court time.

4. Filing Mechanics
• Upload each document as its own PDF, in the order prescribed by the e-portal (motion, memo, exhibits, proposed order).
• Verify that the e-filing category matches the relief sought—mislabeling can delay routing to chambers.

5. Service and Follow-Up
• Serve all parties through the e-portal and send a courtesy copy to chambers if the judge’s procedures call for it.
• Docket follow-ups: Set reminders for the opposition due date, your reply, and any hearing-scheduling window so nothing slips.

6. Strategy Considerations
• Judge-specific preferences matter; a quick call to the judicial assistant can clarify whether oral argument will be granted and how far out the calendar is booking.
• Where time permits, consider filing a short notice of intent to file the motion—sometimes that alone prompts informal resolution.

I hope these touchpoints are helpful. Let me know if you’d like to discuss any of them in more depth.

Best regards,

Jane"}

formatted_items.content: Your reply to Mark has been sent. Let me know if you’d like any tweaks or additions!
